Gharter by King Robcrt the Third, proceeding on Act of Parh’ament passed at Scone on the last day of February 1400-1, whereby, on the narra- tive that a complaint was presented on behalf of the Friars Preachers of St. Katerine of Ayr, stating that King Alexander had endowed them with 3820 sterling yearly out of the royal customs of the said town, which endowment was confirmed by each of his successors, nevertheless the said friars were informed that the king had now set, or proposed to set, the burgh itself at perpetual farm to the burgesses for ,⁴810 of annual rent; on which com- plaint it was ordained by the King and Parliament that no set or infeftment made or to be made aster the said endowment‚ in prejudice of the said friars' infeftmen't thereos, should be of any force, and that the said town shall not be set at a less farm than that contained in the infeftment of the said

friars. Griven under the testimonial of the Great Seal, at Aberdeen 30th March 1401.
